content: The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is introduced, which includes a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" introduces a tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage for individuals, their spouses, and dependents. The credit is limited by monthly caps for eligible coverage months. The tax credit for health insurance coverage is limited by monthly caps for eligible coverage months, with a maximum amount of $1,500 per individual per month. The tax credit for health insurance coverage is limited to $1,500 per individual per month, with a maximum of 2 individuals per taxpayer under this subsection. The term 'eligible coverage month' refers to any month where the individual meets certain criteria. The term 'eligible coverage month' refers to a month where an individual is covered by qualified health insurance paid by the taxpayer for at least a 12-month period. The individual must be covered by qualified health insurance paid by the taxpayer for at least a 12-month period, and not eligible for any employer-provided group health plan to qualify for certain tax benefits based on adjusted gross income. The individual must have been without qualified health insurance and ineligible for an employer-provided group health plan for a specific month to qualify for certain tax benefits based on adjusted gross income. The amount excluded from gross income under specific sections is rounded to the next lowest $10. The applicable dollar amount for qualified health insurance coverage is $60,000 for a taxpayer covering more than one individual and $30,000 for others or married individuals filing separately. Marital status is determined under section 7703 for this purpose. For qualified health insurance, marital status is determined under section 7703. Qualified health insurance refers to insurance covering medical care, excluding insurance with coverage mainly of excepted benefits. The term 'qualified health insurance' refers to insurance covering medical care, excluding coverage mainly of excepted benefits or if less than 50 percent of the cost is borne by the taxpayer. The Indian Health Care Improvement Act is included in the list of government-provided programs that do not qualify for a tax credit for qualified health insurance. A new section is added for the deduction of qualified health insurance costs for employees and self-employed individuals. In general, individuals can deduct the amount paid for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Special rules apply, such as not being able to double-dip with other medical deductions and the deduction not being allowed for self-employment tax purposes. The amount paid for insurance under subsection (a) is not considered for deductions under section 162(l) or 213(a).
